Expectation1: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation1: A customer brings a child’s wooden toy that is broken, and the carpenter should provide a repair quote
Expectation2: Leading the daily prayers in the mosque
Situation2: A large gathering has assembled for a special remembrance, and no one else present is authorized to lead.
Story: I was sanding down a splintered edge on a child’s wooden toy when a worried mother entered my workshop, her little boy clutching the broken train. She pleaded for a quick repair and a quote, explaining it was his favorite and he wouldn’t sleep without it. I examined the damage, already calculating the time and materials needed, when my phone buzzed urgently. It was the mosque committee—an unexpected crowd had gathered for a special remembrance, and I was the only imam available to lead the prayer. My hands, still dusty with sawdust, trembled as I looked at the hopeful faces before me. The mother’s eyes were full of expectation, and the boy’s trust was palpable. Yet, I could almost hear the hum of voices waiting at the mosque, relying on me for spiritual guidance. Both roles demanded my presence, both were urgent in their own way. My heart pounded as I stood between the call of my craft and the call to prayer, torn by the weight of responsibility pressing from both sides.
